org.threadly.concurrent.future

Class ChainedRunnableListenableFuture<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.threadly.concurrent.future.ChainedRunnableListenableFuture<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The result object type returned by this future
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable, java.util.concurrent.Future<T>, java.util.concurrent.RunnableFuture<T>, ListenableFuture<T>, ListenableRunnableFuture<T>

    public class ChainedRunnableListenableFuture<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements ListenableRunnableFuture<T>

    This class makes it easier to chain together work units that need to return a future. It ensures that execution happens on an Executor, but allows you to gain performance improvements by reducing thread thrashing.

    The way to use this is to construct this class to wrap a Callable. Then add this class as a listener using ListenableFuture.addListener(Runnable) (NOT the one that accepts an executor). When this class executes (from when the future completes), it ensures that it is running on the thread pool that the original future completed on. If it is not (because the Future completed before the ListenableFuture.addListener(Runnable) call) then it will submit for execution on the Executor that was provided at construction time.

    This instance can then be returned as the ListenableFuture.

    For chaining work where you know you will need the result from one future before the result of the last one, you can get substantial performance improvements by reducing the load on the thread pool. Instead of releasing the thread back to the pool, after execution completed on the first future, it immediately starts execution on this. So this only makes sense where execution on the pool is likely longer running than the submission rate.

    Some important notes to keep in mind with this...

    • If you chain too many listeners together, eventually a stack overflow is possible.
    • Because futures may live longer than previously, you may want to consider passing in a ClearOnGetSettableListenableFuture into the constructor ChainedRunnableListenableFuture(Thread, SettableListenableFuture, Executor, Callable).
    • This only makes sense in some specific conditions, specifically with high quantity of tasks which run for more than a few hundred milliseconds.

      • ChainedRunnableListenableFuture

        public ChainedRunnableListenableFuture(java.util.concurrent.Executor executor,
                               java.util.concurrent.Callable<? extends T> callable)
        Constructs a new ChainedRunnableListenableFuture.
        Parameters:
        executor - Executor to submit execution on if execution starts on the same thread constructed
        callable - Callable to invoke for result to satisfy the future

      • ChainedRunnableListenableFuture

        public ChainedRunnableListenableFuture(SettableListenableFuture<T> backingFuture,
                               java.util.concurrent.Executor executor,
                               java.util.concurrent.Callable<? extends T> callable)
        Constructs a new ChainedRunnableListenableFuture. This constructor lets you control the backing SettableListenableFuture implementation. The most common use case of this would be to substitute a ClearOnGetSettableListenableFuture to avoid possibly increasing memory load from using this. If using that future be sure to understand the restrictions of only being able to query for the result once.
        Parameters:
        backingFuture - Future to use internally to maintain the result for the future
        executor - Executor to submit execution on if execution starts on the same thread constructed
        callable - Callable to invoke for result to satisfy the future

      • ChainedRunnableListenableFuture

        public ChainedRunnableListenableFuture(java.lang.Thread creationThread,
                               java.util.concurrent.Executor executor,
                               java.util.concurrent.Callable<? extends T> callable)
        Constructs a new ChainedRunnableListenableFuture. This constructor allows you to control what Thread it should use to consider it's "creation" thread. If execution starts on this thread, the task will be re-submitted to the provided Executor.
        Parameters:
        creationThread - Reference thread for execution, if execution happens on this thread it will be re-executed
        executor - Executor to submit execution on if execution starts on the same thread constructed
        callable - Callable to invoke for result to satisfy the future

      • ChainedRunnableListenableFuture

        public ChainedRunnableListenableFuture(java.lang.Thread creationThread,
                               SettableListenableFuture<T> backingFuture,
                               java.util.concurrent.Executor executor,
                               java.util.concurrent.Callable<? extends T> callable)
        Constructs a new ChainedRunnableListenableFuture. This constructor lets you control the backing SettableListenableFuture implementation. The most common use case of this would be to substitute a ClearOnGetSettableListenableFuture to avoid possibly increasing memory load from using this. If using that future be sure to understand the restrictions of only being able to query for the result once. This constructor also allows you to control what Thread it should use to consider it's "creation" thread. If execution starts on this thread, the task will be re-submitted to the provided Executor.
        Parameters:
        creationThread - Reference thread for execution, if execution happens on this thread it will be re-executed
        backingFuture - Future to use internally to maintain the result for the future
        executor - Executor to submit execution on if execution starts on the same thread constructed
        callable - Callable to invoke for result to satisfy the future

      • addListener

        public void addListener(java.lang.Runnable listener)
        Description copied from interface: ListenableFuture
        Add a listener to be called once the future has completed. If the future has already finished, this will be called immediately. The listener from this call will execute on the same thread the result was produced on, or on the adding thread if the future is already complete. If the runnable has high complexity, consider passing an Executor in for it to be ran on.
        Specified by:
        addListener in interface ListenableFuture<T>
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to run when the computation is complete

      • addListener

        public void addListener(java.lang.Runnable listener,
               java.util.concurrent.Executor executor)
        Description copied from interface: ListenableFuture
        Add a listener to be called once the future has completed. If the future has already finished, this will be called immediately. If the provided Executor is null, the listener will execute on the thread which computed the original future (once it is done). If the future has already completed, the listener will execute immediately on the thread which is adding the listener.
        Specified by:
        addListener in interface ListenableFuture<T>
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to run when the computation is complete
        executor - Executor the listener should be ran on, or null

      • addCallback

        public void addCallback(FutureCallback<? super T> callback)
        Description copied from interface: ListenableFuture
        Add a FutureCallback to be called once the future has completed. If the future has already finished, this will be called immediately. The callback from this call will execute on the same thread the result was produced on, or on the adding thread if the future is already complete. If the callback has high complexity, consider passing an executor in for it to be called on.
        Specified by:
        addCallback in interface ListenableFuture<T>
        Parameters:
        callback - to be invoked when the computation is complete
